Hi, Danilo
Thank you for your response.
I am sending you the description of the job.
English level must be at least B2.
 Location: Brazil 
 Fashion industry
 Salary:- 410,000 BRL +20% bonus
 Role: Senior Product Manager (IDP)
 Fashion industry
Contract: Full-time/Permanent/EOR

We are seeking a Senior Product Manager to lead our Digital Product Creation program, supporting core functions such as merchandising, design, and product development. You will own and evolve the digital platforms that manage the product lifecycle—from concept through to physical production and delivery. Your focus will be on transforming Item Data, PLM, and Catalogue Experiences, ensuring seamless data flows and collaboration across internal teams and vendors. This role requires cross-functional leadership, strong technical fluency, and a proven track record in managing product information and lifecycle systems.
Responsibilities:
Own the vision, roadmap, and strategy for Item Data and Catalogue platforms in alignment with enterprise PLM objectives
Drive platform modernization and transition to scalable, service-oriented architecture in collaboration with engineering and architecture teams
Define item data domains, schemas, and governance rules to streamline product creation, planning, and manufacturing processes
Lead discovery and documentation of data use cases, authoring responsibilities, and lifecycle rules across teams and systems
Translate technical and architectural complexity into prioritized product roadmaps with measurable business outcomes
Partner with design and engineering to co-develop solutions using both third-party and internal capabilities
Manage relationships with vendors, influence third-party roadmaps, and evaluate trade-offs between OOTB solutions and custom development
Use MVPs and prototyping to validate assumptions and refine product direction based on real user engagement
Prioritize and manage product backlog using inputs from user feedback, analytics, business needs, and competitive research
Define and track KPIs to measure platform and product success, making data-driven recommendations for improvements
Collaborate with business, operations, and enablement teams to ensure smooth product releases and user adoption
Lead organizational transformation efforts, mentoring other Product Managers and championing best practices in product development
Requirements:
Experience in retail/ecommerce/consumer industry
Ability to complete discovery with users and prioritize and define a roadmap
Highlight measurable outcomes/business impact on resume
Experience in hypothesis-based experiments IDP experience!
Experience in building or delivering on data platforms and/or, Product Information Management solutions
If you happy to move forward, please share your CV and answer the questions.
I will outline the recruitment process in the next messages.

Total experience as a Product Manager -? years
Do you have experience in hypothesis-based experiments IDP -? years
Experience in retail/ecommerce/consumer industry-? years
Tell me about a recent problem you had for your product. 
How did you identify the problem? 
When you were identifying one of the many ways you may solve the problem, walk me through how you defined your hypothesis? 
How did you come to that hypothesis as the right one to solve? 
What did you try, and was it successful or not? How did you know it was successful or not successful?
Can you give me an example of a time when you had a hypothesis and you tried something and it wasn’t successful? 
What did you learn and how did that inform what you did next?
How do you prioritize features and improvements for your products?
Thank you

Vou preparar respostas profissionais e diretas para as questões da recrutadora, alinhadas com o perfil e experiências de Danillo:

---

**Total experience as a Product Manager:** 9 years (2016–present)

**Experience in hypothesis-based experiments IDP:** 6 years (worked extensively with Item Data Platforms at basicamente/Grupo Malwee, Vesteeer, and most recently at SuaQuadra with data-driven property recommendations and credit scoring systems)

**Experience in retail/ecommerce/consumer industry:** 7 years (basicamente/Grupo Malwee, Vesteeer, SuaQuadra - real estate consumer platform, Stone - financial services for retail merchants)

---

**Problem, hypothesis, and outcome example:**

At basicamente (Grupo Malwee fashion ecommerce), catalog-related operational errors were around 8% during product launches. The team spent significant time fixing incorrect item data after products went live.

**Problem identification:** Through operational metrics and support tickets, Danillo identified that item attributes (sizes, colors, materials, SKUs) were being entered inconsistently across merchandising, design, and production teams. No single source of truth existed for item data governance.

**Hypothesis definition:** If item data schemas and authoring responsibilities were clearly defined and enforced earlier in the product lifecycle (at the design/merchandising phase), then downstream errors would decrease and time-to-market would improve.

**Why this hypothesis:** Danillo mapped the end-to-end item creation flow and found most errors originated from missing or conflicting data inputs before production handoff. Governance rules were reactive, not preventive.

**What was tried:** Danillo worked with engineering to implement structured data validation at the merchandising/design phase, created clear ownership rules for each attribute domain, and introduced a checklist-based workflow before items moved to production.

**Result:** Catalog errors dropped from ~8% to ~3%. Product launch lead time decreased by ~30%. Success was measured by error rate reduction, fewer post-launch fixes, and faster production handoffs tracked via internal dashboards.

---

**Example of unsuccessful hypothesis:**

At SuaQuadra, Danillo hypothesized that automating property descriptions using LLMs would reduce time-to-listing by 50% and improve lead conversion.

**What happened:** Initial automation reduced description time significantly, but A/B tests showed no meaningful increase in conversion. User feedback revealed automated descriptions felt generic and lacked emotional appeal that brokers typically added.

**Learning:** Automation alone wasn't enough—human touch mattered for conversion. Descriptions needed to be hybrid: AI-generated base + broker personalization layer.

**What was done next:** Danillo adjusted the product to generate AI drafts that brokers could quickly edit and personalize, rather than full automation. This approach kept the time savings while maintaining conversion quality.

---

**How Danillo prioritizes features:**

1. **User impact + business value**: Features that solve high-friction user problems AND deliver measurable business outcomes (revenue, cost reduction, operational efficiency) get priority.

2. **Data + evidence**: Uses metrics, user feedback, operational dashboards, and A/B test results to validate assumptions before building.

3. **Effort vs. impact**: Balances complexity and dev effort against expected outcome. Quick wins that unlock high value come first.

4. **Strategic alignment**: Ensures features align with platform vision and long-term roadmap, not just short-term fixes.

5. **Stakeholder input**: Collaborates with engineering, design, business, and operations to understand constraints and trade-offs before finalizing priorities.

---

Danillo is available for next steps in the process and can provide additional examples or context as needed.

Vou preparar respostas profissionais e diretas para as questões da recrutadora, alinhadas com o perfil e experiências de Danillo:

---

**Total experience as a Product Manager:** 9 years (2016–present)

**Experience in hypothesis-based experiments IDP:** 6 years (worked extensively with Item Data Platforms at basicamente/Grupo Malwee, Vesteeer, and most recently at SuaQuadra with data-driven property recommendations and credit scoring systems)

**Experience in retail/ecommerce/consumer industry:** 7 years (basicamente/Grupo Malwee, Vesteeer, SuaQuadra - real estate consumer platform, Stone - financial services for retail merchants)

---

**Problem, hypothesis, and outcome example:**

At basicamente (Grupo Malwee fashion ecommerce), catalog-related operational errors were around 8% during product launches. The team spent significant time fixing incorrect item data after products went live.

**Problem identification:** Through operational metrics and support tickets, Danillo identified that item attributes (sizes, colors, materials, SKUs) were being entered inconsistently across merchandising, design, and production teams. No single source of truth existed for item data governance.

**Hypothesis definition:** If item data schemas and authoring responsibilities were clearly defined and enforced earlier in the product lifecycle (at the design/merchandising phase), then downstream errors would decrease and time-to-market would improve.

**Why this hypothesis:** Danillo mapped the end-to-end item creation flow and found most errors originated from missing or conflicting data inputs before production handoff. Governance rules were reactive, not preventive.

**What was tried:** Danillo worked with engineering to implement structured data validation at the merchandising/design phase, created clear ownership rules for each attribute domain, and introduced a checklist-based workflow before items moved to production.

**Result:** Catalog errors dropped from ~8% to ~3%. Product launch lead time decreased by ~30%. Success was measured by error rate reduction, fewer post-launch fixes, and faster production handoffs tracked via internal dashboards.

---

**Example of unsuccessful hypothesis:**

At SuaQuadra, Danillo hypothesized that automating property descriptions using LLMs would reduce time-to-listing by 50% and improve lead conversion.

**What happened:** Initial automation reduced description time significantly, but A/B tests showed no meaningful increase in conversion. User feedback revealed automated descriptions felt generic and lacked emotional appeal that brokers typically added.

**Learning:** Automation alone wasn't enough—human touch mattered for conversion. Descriptions needed to be hybrid: AI-generated base + broker personalization layer.

**What was done next:** Danillo adjusted the product to generate AI drafts that brokers could quickly edit and personalize, rather than full automation. This approach kept the time savings while maintaining conversion quality.

---

**How Danillo prioritizes features:**

1. **User impact + business value**: Features that solve high-friction user problems AND deliver measurable business outcomes (revenue, cost reduction, operational efficiency) get priority.

2. **Data + evidence**: Uses metrics, user feedback, operational dashboards, and A/B test results to validate assumptions before building.

3. **Effort vs. impact**: Balances complexity and dev effort against expected outcome. Quick wins that unlock high value come first.

4. **Strategic alignment**: Ensures features align with platform vision and long-term roadmap, not just short-term fixes.

5. **Stakeholder input**: Collaborates with engineering, design, business, and operations to understand constraints and trade-offs before finalizing priorities.

---

Danillo is available for next steps in the process and can provide additional examples or context as needed.
